content.description:
Easy climbing for first 3 bolts, then navigate some corner climbing using palm presses and high feet through the next two bolts. Just when it feels too off-balance, you get a nice jug. Then move out onto the arete to a great left hand sloper high up. The rest is a cruise. Not sustained like other 11.b's in the area.
This route is very long, and very exciting! There are 3 rap stations on the route to facilitate cleaning/lowering, might be best done in two pitches. 

7 bolts to first anchor, 17 bolts for full route

climbs.name: Bloodsport
climbs.fa: Mischi Boehnisch FFA and Peter Arbic '93

content.description:
The extension to Public Enemy.  Do not clip that routes anchors, but rather climb the face to the right of the ledge.  Low angle climbing for 10 meters leads to the roofs.  Weave your way up and left via underclings and big reaches between horizontals.  The top dihedral is a real treat.  Enjoy the view, it is unbeatable.

Tiered roofs above Public Enemy
~20 bolts.  Lower twice with a 60m rope, an 80 may make it to the ground from the top, be careful.  Wise extending and back cleaning to reduce drag is a good idea.

Climb the obvious crack before traversing right to clip the four bolts above to the anchor.

Gear to 2" + four bolts.

Start at a low and obvious bolt near a tree. Make a few tricky slab moves on thin holds, and pull the small roof to the first set of anchors (5.8). Continue up a steep and blocky section to the second set of anchors. A 70m rope is enough to lower from there.

Between Raindogs and Blue Valentine
10+ bolts

Climb through sequence after sequence of thought-provoking and fun moves all the way up the arete.  A little bit balancey and three-dimensional.

The bolted line on the arete to the right of Wicked Gravity.  I think there's one route in the 5.12 range that pulls a large roof in between Chocolate Bunnies and Wicked Gravity.
bolts

Climb Pub Night to the anchor.  Continue clipping pitons above to finish at the obvious anchor above.

Gear to 4" until the first anchor.  Many pitons on the second pitch with no need for gear.

Balancey vertical climbing leads to a roof. Crank through the cruxy roof, make a few big pulls above, and then cruise up more vertical climbing to the anchor. Gorgeous line.

Immediately right of Wicked Gravity.
Bolts. Fixed quickdraw at the crux.

"Climb a wide crack just right of the tree growing on the wall. Finish at the top of a large, left-facing corner. A bit vegetated to start"

Obvious crack splitting the wall with most of the easy sport routes on the left side of Outhouse wall. Anchors are up and about 2m left of the fall line, so put in a cam for a redirect if top-roping. Standard Rockies rack 0.4-3 cams and set of nuts will give you lots of options. Excellent beginner trad route.



Obvious large crack on the left side of outhouse area. Tree growing in the start.

Standard Rockies rack, 2 bolts/ chained rap ring at anchors.

This route has plenty of protection, with large blocks to work around inside a varying offwidth. 

From the outhouse, head down the trail until it starts to go up again. The route is immediately to the right of DEW Line (Air Voyage Wall). 
Gear to 4", bolted anchors.

Thin face climbing after pitch 1 of DBS crack. One crux move on thin holds early on leads to easier climbing.

Second pitch of DSB trad climb
bolts

To the right of Topgun. Great route with ledges and crimps. First bolt is very high up, PG13 if you don't use pro for the start, super safe otherwise. Traverse to the right to reach the Pub Night anchor. It is better to have a follower to clean due to the weird traverse. 



To the right of Top Gun

Bolts + optional gear

The dry weather anchors for Venom-

Climb Venom, and instead of clipping the chains under the roof just right of the arête, step left onto the face and continue up. Once on the face, 2 bolts protect a rightward traverse to an airy rest straddling a horn. Pull the roof (mega exposed) and head for the chains above. 

Probably smart to set up your belay stance on the ledge above Mardi Gras- the rope weight becomes obscene if you don't. Long draw the first bolt on Venom. 

Lower/rap in 2. 



Look for the prominent Venom arête which is ~20 m above where the low angle terrain on Outhouse Wall starts. Approach via Mardi Gras (long draw everything) or Turtle Mountain (skip the first 3 bolts, long draw the 4th) if you're going for the full 46 m monster pitch.  

10 bolts, 2 bolt anchor with biners.

Climb the left facing corner (gear) to a stance with two bolts on the left side of a overhanging arete. Traverse right, then climb straight up on long moves with huge high steps. Sustained climbing leads to a thin crux just under the chains. Classic!

Just left of Turtle Mountain
Small cams or nuts for the 5.3 corner then 6 bolts + anchor

The first half of this climb follows a nice 5.7 crack system and is protected by gear. An intermediate anchor sits atop this portion and many stop here. This makes for a fun trad pitch. 
  
 The second half is a bolt protected climb up a steep 5.10 face.

Crack system just left of Blue Valentine and just  right of a tree growing out of the bottom of the wall.
Standard rack of nuts and cams to BD #2. There are two sets of bolted anchors and one can choose to stop after the easier first half or continue to the top.

Start up the slab and clip a bolt before turning the arete and climbing up steeply on small positive holds. The crux comes before the roof, on small cracks. then pull over and haul jugs to the anchor.

Just right of Turtle Island, climbs a small roof.
Bolts

Fun face climbing up overlaps on gray rock leafs to a second easier pitch on the juggy yellow face above.

Near the far left side of the crag. The second bolted line left of the wide crack with a tree.
Bolts. From the second anchor, one 70 gets you close enough to the ground to downclimb easily, but watch the ends!

Easy climb   

6 bolts

Another fine and easy outing that is well protected on the left side of the Outhouse Wall. Slightly more exciting than its neighbor to the right. A couple tricky moves gain a large chalked hold under a small bulge. Clip a high bolt and make a somewhat burly pull up and around to the left of this bulge. Work your way up the corner and mantle onto a small ledge system (watch your head!). Find the good hold up and to the right, step out high right, and pull up to jugs. Finish on super easy low-angle terrain up a small corner to the anchors. Fun!

Last bolted route on the left before the trail goes steeply downhill.
Bolts to chains

The classic hard line at Louise. An unbelievable pitch.



Climb Wicked Gravity, and keep going.

small cams and nuts

Climb the obvious corner left of Wicked Gravity wall.

Gear to 4".

well protected and a good intro to the area

9 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor

Climbs the pretty purple tinged rock through the roof and onto the yellow face above. Delicate face climbing leads to a sidepull problem below the roof. Figure it out, clip the bolt above, and head up to the technical, puzzling crux. After the next bolt, easier terrain leads to the anchor.

Just right of Mardi Gras, climbs the same roof.
Bolts

"Climb a crack leading through a yellow wall to an arching corner and the hardest moves. Jugs lead over the roof to the anchor"

A thin crack left of the big purple corner "Tomcat". The route goes left at the roof, not following the thin crack at this point. Mostly nuts or cams below 0.4 until 2m below the roof, there is a good 0.75 placement. One bolt above the roof, then chain anchors with a rap ring.



Thin crack through a yellow wall left of "Tomcat" purple left facing corner. (Second major corner left of wicked gravity wall)

Only small nuts/microcams until about halfway, then small to medium gear. One bolt at about 17 m. Rap ring chained to 2 bolts at anchor.

Start as Purple People Eater. After the 3rd bolt go right to reach the last bolt of the route. Follow the crack up to the anchor of public enemy. Some sections can be a bit runout, but the protections are great!



Same start as Purple People Eater. Finish at public enemy's anchor.

4 bolts + gear.

What's this? A 5.7 that requires both pulling and good footwork? A fine first lead, well protected. Start by making a tricky move or two off the deck up the slab. From here, launch into an "armsy" pull over a small overhang through a bulge on great holds with good feet and find yourself on a slab. A couple moves later the good holds disappear. Think "right" and "high step" and "slab technique" to make your way up to the anchors, situated at a great stance. 
  
 Excellent rock quality on fine black rock, though a couple holds up top are somewhat sandy.

Second route from the left on the Outhouse wall just before the trail goes steeply back downhill.
Bolts to chains.

Starts up discontinuous cracks to a horizontal leading right (gear protected). 
 Clip a few bolts up to the anchor. This pitch is 5.7 and may be called Blue Valentine. The second pitch tackles the steeper face above, fully bolt protected.

In the middle of the slab at the left side on the crag, a few metres right of a wide crack with a tree.
Bolts and a few pieces of gear, up to a .75 BD worked for me. A 70 is long enough to TR both pitches linked.

This was my favorite of the moderate trad climbs at Outhouse Wall. Climb up low angle, nicely featured rock to a small ledge at the base of a big black streak using a crack for protection. Continue up an interesting flake system on the left side of the streak. Follow a thin seam to a good ledge and the anchor. The protection here is adequate but not plentiful (small cams and nuts). There is one well placed bolt where the seam pinches down and won't accept protection. The Bow Valley Sport guidebook by Derek Galloway mentions two protection bolts but one has been chopped.

Look for a big black streak on the right end of the wall, just a bit left of the obvious corner system of Pub Night.
Cams from BD 0.2 to 1 and a set of nuts.

Really fun movement with fun exposure!

7 bolts and 2 bolt anchor

Hard to say if there is a better pitch at the lake than this!  Venom is the hanging arete above Turtle Mountain.

Climb any route below the arete to get to the midway anchors (Mardi Gras is most fun but judicious back cleaning is advised).  Graciously extend the bolt above the belay and continue towards the arete.  Things get pretty pumpy as the reaches between horizontals keep coming.  

Lower twice with a 60  

arete above turtle mountain
lots of extendable draws

Sweet route, fun movement and well protected.

7 bolts and anchors

The outhouse wall has a selection of climbs at all grades and is a sure fire place to find routes that you'll want to climb no matter the grade you are after.

The views back along the lake to the Chateau are worth an hour or two of belay duty!

There is a namesake outhouse along the downhill trail after the left-most routes.
